One way to ask why this combination of syn -  tactic and semantic roles is favored is to ask what is wrong with the other ones. What rules out the combinations ( 1 ), ( 2 ), and ( 3 )? What sort of consideration could? The strategy pursued here is to look at the constraints on the expressive power of a language that are imposed by each of those varieties of complex substitutional roles.  The first alternative is a good place to begin, for it is fairly easily eliminated from contention. The semantic point of discerning subsentential structure substitutionally is to codify an antecedent field of inferential proprieties concerning sentences by associating material contents with recombinable subsentential expressions so as to be able to derive those proprieties of inference, and to pro -  ject further ones, according to a general pattern of substitution -  inferential significance of material substitutional commitments. But the substituted-in sentences whose inferences are to be codi -  fied themselves stand in “one-way inferential involvements.” The goodness of an inference may require that when the conclusion is substituted for the premise(s), some status (doxastic or as -  sertional commitment, truth, and so on) is preserved. But the converse replacement need not preserve that status. Substitution inferences are not always reversible, saving correctness. Conclu -  sions are often inferentially weaker than the premises from which they are inferred. A restriction to sentential contents confer -  rable by exclusively symmetrically valid material inferences is a restriction to sentential contents completely unrecognizable as such by us. The Normative Character of Concept Use  The rationale for such a claim emerges most clearly from consider -  ation of certain very general features of discursive practice. Here it is useful to start with another of Kant’s fundamental insights, into the   normative   character of the significance of what is conceptually contentful. His idea is that judgments and actions are above all things that we are   responsible   for. Kant understands concepts as having the form of   rules,   which is to say that they specify how something   ought   (according to the rule) to be done. The under -  standing, the conceptual faculty, is the faculty of grasping rules, of appreciating the distinction between correct and incorrect appli -  cation they determine. Judgings and doings are acts that have contents that one can take or make true and for which the demand for reasons is in order. What is distinctive about them is the way they are governed by rules. Being in an intentional state or per -  forming an intentional action has a normative significance. It counts as undertaking (acquiring) an obligation or commitment; the content of the commitment is determined by the rules that are the concepts in terms of which the act or state is articulated. Thus Kant picks us out as distinctively normative or rule-governed creatures. Taking it that the claim expressed by one sentence entails the claim expressed by another is treating anyone who is committed to the first as thereby com -  mitted to the second. We typically think about inference solely in terms of the relation between premise and conclusion, that is, as a monological relation among propositional contents. Second, the scorekeeper must  attribute   a sort of inferential   entitlement   to that commitment. This corresponds to the   justification   condition on knowledge. What is it that then corresponds to the third,   truth   condition on knowledge? For the scorekeeper to take the attributed claim to be true is just for the scorekeeper to endorse that claim. The classical metaphysics of truth properties misconstrues what one is doing in endorsing the claim as   describing   in a special way. According to the model I started with, propositional, that is, assertible, contents are inferentially articulated. Grasping such a content is being able to distinguish in practice what should follow from endorsing it, and what such endorsement should follow from. But the consequences of endorsing a given claim depends on what other commitments are available to be employed as auxil -  iary hypotheses in the inference. The ascriber of a doxastic com -  mitment has two different perspectives available from which to draw those auxiliary hypotheses in specifying the content of the commitment being ascribed: that of the one to whom it is  ascribed   and that of the one   ascribing   it. Where the specification of the content depends only on auxiliary premises that (according to the ascriber) the target of the ascription   acknowledges   being com -  mitted to, though the ascriber may not, it is put in   de dicto   posi -  tion, within the ‘that’ clause. Where the specification of the content depends on auxiliary premises that the   ascriber   endorses, but the target of the ascription may not, it is put in   de re   position. Conclusion  I have claimed that the primary representational locution in ordi -  nary language, the one we use to talk about the representationa l  Copyright © 2000 The President and Fellows of Harvard College

It is the role they play in such ascriptions that gives their meanings to the ‘of ’ or ‘about’ we use to express intentional directedness. I have also claimed that the expressive role of these locutions is to make explicit the distinction of social perspective involved in keeping our books straight on who is committed to what. The social dimension of inference involved in the communication to others of claims that must be available as reasons both to the speaker and to the audience, in spite of differences in collateral commitments, is what underlies the representational dimension of discourse.  Beliefs and claims that are   propositionally   contentful are neces -  sarily   representationally   contentful because their inferential ar -  ticulation   essentially   involves   a   social   dimension.   That   social dimension is unavoidable because the inferential significance of a claim, the appropriate antecedents and consequences of a doxastic commitment, depends on the background of collateral commit -  ments available for service as auxiliary hypotheses. Thus any speci -  fication   of   a   propositional   content   must   be   made   from   the perspective of some such set of commitments. One wants to say that the   correct   inferential role is determined by the collateral claims that are   true.   Just so; that is what   each   interlocutor wants to say: each has an at least slightly different perspective from which to   evaluate   inferential   proprieties.   Representational   locutions make explicit the sorting of commitments into those attributed and those undertaken—without which communication would be impossible, given those differences of perspective. The   representa -  tional   dimension of propositional contents reflects the   social  structure of their   inferential   articulation in the game of giving and asking for reasons. Semantic Assertibilism  A basic pragmatist methodological thesis is that the point of the theoretical association of   meanings   with linguistic expressions is to explain the   use   of those expressions. (Semantics must answer to pragmatics.) A fundamental divide among theorists who agree in endorsing this methodological pragmatism then concerns the terms in which the use of linguistic expressions is understood. One camp takes as its explanatory target   proprieties   of use. Mean -  ings are invoked to explain how it is   correct   or   appropriate   to use words and sentences, how one   ought   to deploy them. The other camp (Quinean behaviorists may serve as an example) insists on specifying the use to be explained in sparer terms. The ultimate explanatory target at which semantic theory aims is utterances and dispositions to utter described in a vocabulary resolutely restricted to nonnormative terms. 1   I will say something further along about why I think the second camp is misguided. But for now I just want to put this option to one side, with the observation that doing so does not by itself require relinquishing commitments to naturalis -  tic semantics. For one might well accept a normative characteriza -  tion of the explanatory target—specifying use in terms that permit one to distinguish, say, correct from incorrect representations of  Copyright © 2000 The President and Fellows of Harvard College

II.   Giving and Asking for Reasons  Semantic assertibilism is implicitly committed to demarcating specifically   linguistic   practices by restricting that term to practices that confer on some performances the significance of   claims   or  assertions.   What is assert ed   in an act of assert ing,   what is assert ible,  is a propositional content. Assertible contents, assertibles, are also believables and judgeables; states of belief and acts of judgment can accordingly be expressed by assertions. Linguistic expressions whose freestanding utterances have the default significance of assertions are (declarative) sentences. My aim is to investigate the propositional contents that are associated with linguistic expres -  sions by their playing this central role in assertional practices.  The first key idea is that a performance deserves to count as hav -  ing the significance of an assertion only in the context of a set of social practices with the structure of (in Sellars’s phrase) a   game of giving and asking for reasons.   Assertions are essentially perfor -  mances that can both serve as and stand in need of reasons. Propositional contents are essentially what can serve as both premises and conclusions of inferences. This inferentialist idea might be called ‘linguistic rationalism’. 4   Linguistic rationalism is not a standard part of the armamentarium of semantic assertibil -  ism, but I think it is what is required to make that explanatory strategy work. I suggested in Chapter   1   what seem to me good reasons to see giving and asking for reasons as the defining core of  Copyright © 2000 The President and Fellows of Harvard College

Rather, I want to treat linguistic rationalism as a hypothesis, and to explore its consequences.  In the rest of this chapter I make two arguments. First, in this section I argue that no set of practices is recognizable as a game of giving and asking for reasons for assertions unless it involves acknowledging at least two sorts of normative status,   commit -  ments   and   entitlements,   and some general structures relating them. I show how we can understand practices incorporating those statuses in that structure as conferring propositional con -  tents on linguistic expressions suitably caught up in them. Suppose we have a set of counters or markers such that produc -  ing or playing one has the social significance of making an asser -  tional move in the game. We can call such counters ‘sentences’. Then for any player at any time there must be a way of partition -  ing sentences into two classes, by distinguishing somehow those that he is disposed or otherwise prepared to assert (perhaps when suitably prompted). These counters, which are distinguished by bearing the player’s mark, being on his list, or being kept in his box, constitute his score. By playing a new counter, making an assertion, one alters one’s own score, and perhaps that of others.  Here is my first claim: for such a game or set of toy practices to be recognizable as involving assertions, it must be the case that playing one counter, or otherwise adding it to one’s score, can  commit   one to playing others, or adding them to one’s score. If one asserts, “The swatch is red,” one   ought   to add to one’s score also “The swatch is colored.” Making the one move   obliges   one to be prepared to make the other as well. If putting sentences onto my list or into my box   never   has consequences for what else belongs there, then we ought not to understand the list as consisting of all my judgments, or the box as containing all my beliefs. III.   Objectivity  What I want to do in this final section is to demonstrate one of the semantic payoffs that this richer pragmatic structure enables.  Assertibilist semantic theories seek to understand propositional content by associating with sentences as their semantic interpre -  tants   assertibility conditions:   circumstances under which the sen -  tence in question is appropriately assertible. The attraction of such theories is due to the very close tie they establish between meaning and use. They hold out the promise of reading   semantic   norms  Copyright © 2000 The President and Fellows of Harvard College

The challenge for them is to get out the other end of their machinery a sense of ‘correct’ that is suffi -  ciently objective to be recognizable as a notion of propositional content. On the face of it, assertional speech acts are subject to two central sorts of normative appraisal. One asks whether the speech act was appropriate in light of the attitudes of the practitioners: Was all available evidence taken into account? Were the inferences made good ones, as far as the practitioners know? In general, did the speaker follow the rules of the game, so as not to be blamewor -  thy for producing the assertion? The other sort of appraisal swings free of the attitudes of the practitioners and looks instead to the subject matter about which claims are made for the applicable norms. Here the central question is: Is the claim correct in the sense that things really are as it says they are? Only an omniscient being could follow a rule enjoining practitioners to make only claims that are true. This means that the conduct of those who, through no fault of their own, make false claims is not blamewor -  thy. Nonetheless, this further sort of appraisal is possible. In order to make their raw materials as intelligible as possible, one wants to tie assertibility closely to people’s attitudes, to what they   take   to be assertible or   treat as   assertible. This need not take the extreme form of identifying the assertibility conditions of sentences with nonnormatively specified conditions under which practitioners are disposed to assert those sentences. One of Frege’s great discoveries was that one must be able to discern predicates in this sense (complex, or sub -  stitutionally derived ones) in order to appreciate the inferential role of sentences like “Anyone who admires someone admires himself.” For one must appreciate the different patterns they instantiate in order to see that in the context of that quantificational claim, “Kant admired Rousseau” entails “Kant admired Kant.” Thus the status of predicates as playing derived substitution-structural roles is what lies behind the second of Strawson’s stigmata distinguishing predicates from singular terms: that they are subject to quantification. Sometimes ‘general points’ are appealed to, whose pro -  jective properties form a proper subset of the projective properties of other points and so are asymmetrically inferentially related to one another in the way sortals can be: particular points have all the prop -  erties of general points but not vice versa. How is this possible? Pro -  jective properties are not closed under Boolean operations such as complementation, and one cannot introduce conditional proper -  ties—a restriction that has sometimes been seen as puzzling. The present argument explains the unobvious connection between the introduction of general points and the exclusion of negation and the conditional from the language in which projective properties are specified. Notice that this characterization of the conclusion could be accepted even by someone who was not persuaded by the expressive approach to understanding the demarcation of specifically logical vocabulary and so the function of logic. It might be noticed in passing that it is   not   harmless to paraphrase this choice as that between talking about how linguistic expressions  ought   to be used, and how they are   actually   or   in fact   used, or how practitioners are   disposed   to use them. Using an expression correctly or incorrectly is something practitioners can actually or in fact do, something they can be disposed to do. The difference should be located rather in the vocabulary the theorist is permitted to use in characterizing what speakers and audiences actually do and are dis -  posed to do. Formulating this difference as a difference between say -  ing how the language   is   used and how it (only)   ought   to be used is the decisive move in the conjuring trick that lands one in the intractable puzzlements about conceptual normativity that Kripke’s Wittgenstein has made familiar.  2 .   I think of Dretske, Fodor, and Millikan as presenting theories with this general shape. Perhaps Gibbard’s very different approach to moral norms, when generalized and adapted to the case of linguistic norms, will find its place here too.  3 .   My thought is that there is no way to specify the ideality in question that is not either question-begging (in implicitly appealing to a notion of truth) or trivial, in the light of the sensitivity of the practi -  cal effects of otherwise more ideal status for one belief both to the  falsity   of collateral beliefs and (even more damaging) to   ignorance  concerning them. It is not identical with inferentialism as introduced in Chapter   1 , since that thesis concerned the relative explanatory priority of the concepts of inference and representation, and linguistic rationalism as used here is silent about representation. In   Making It Explicit   (Cam -  bridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press,   1994 ) [hereafter   MIE   ], I distinguish three sorts of inferentialist claims: weak inferentialism, strong inferentialism, and hyperinferentialism. Weak inferentialism is the claim that inferential articulation is a   necessary   aspect of con -  ceptual content. Strong inferentialism is the claim that   broadly   in -  ferential articulation is   sufficient   to determine conceptual content  Copyright © 2000 The President and Fellows of Harvard College

Hyperinferentialism is the claim that   narrowly   inferential articulation is   sufficient   to deter -  mine conceptual content. Broadly inferential articulation includes as inferential   the   relation   even   between   circumstances   and   conse -  quences of application, even when one or the other is   non inferential (as with observable and immediately practical concepts), since in applying any concept one implicitly endorses the propriety of the inference from its circumstances to its consequences of application. Narrowly inferential articulation is restricted to what Sellars calls “language-language” moves, that is, to the relation between propo -  sitional contents. Weak inferentialism is the most plausible of these theses. Strong inferentialism is the view endorsed and defended here and in   MIE.   (It is sometimes thought that in his classical inferentialist tract “Inference and Meaning” of   1948 , Sellars presents an argument for weak inferentialism but draws strong inferentialist conclusions.) Hyperinferentialism is plausible at most for some abstract mathemat -  ical concepts. Linguistic rationalism is a version of weak inferential -  ism, which the present chapter endeavors to show has some strong inferentialist consequences, when suitably elaborated. It should be remarked that acknowledging incompatibilities means treating the assessment of entitlements as a two-stage process. First, one assesses prima facie claims to entitlement, and then one winnows from this set those commitments that are incompatible with other commitments, and hence precluded from entitlement. What I call (here and in what follows) “entitlement-preserving inferences” struc -  ture the inheritance of prima facie commitments. As Crispin Wright has pointed out (in an unpublished comment on this argument), according to the definitions offered here, if two claims differ in their incompatibilities, they can at most be alike in the circumstances in which one is prima facie entitled to them, not in the circumstances in which one is   finally   entitled to them. The assert -  ibilist tradition did not make this distinction, since it did not divide the undifferentiated status of assertibility into commitment and enti -  tlement in the first place (and hence was not in a position to discuss incompatibility). A fuller telling of this story (such as that in   Making It Explicit ) would distinguish   three   moves beyond classical assertibility theories in order to fund a suitable notion of objective representational content for declarative sentences. The first is the move from treating assertibility as the fundamental normative pragmatic or force-related notion to commitment and entitlement (which then makes it possible to define incompatibility). The second is the move from the   circumstances  under which the normative status in question is acquired (assertibil -  ity conditions) to include also   consequences   of acquiring it, as urged in Chapter   1 . This is moving toward a notion of content as inferential role, identifying propositional contentfulness as suitability to play the role both of conclusion and of premise in inferences of various sorts. The interaction of this move with the previous one generates the three notions of inference (commitment-preserving, entitlement -  preserving, and incompatibility entailments) employed in the text. The third is the move from looking at normative   statuses   (assertibil -  ity, commitment, entitlement) to normative   social attitudes.   This is to focus on   attributing   (to others) and   acknowledging   (oneself ) commitments and so on as the primary phenomenon. In Chapter   5   I argued that this distinction of   social perspective   is what makes intelli -  gible the specifically   representational   dimension of propositional contents. One might have worried, at the end of that story, about how it is possible (what one has to do in order) to adopt, as it were, a third-person perspective toward one’s   own   attitudes, and so take them to be subject in principle to the same sort of assessment to which one subjects the attitudes of others, in offering   de re   specifica -  tions of their contents. translation.plain_english: The normative state of Concrete Universality is achieved when the expansive multiplicity of the parts is perfectly balanced by and identified with the compressive unity of the whole.
translation.source_passage: HERMENEUTIC REFLECTION phase

translation.plain_english: The normative system, once established, becomes self-grounding; it is necessarily implied by its own existence.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Closure

translation.plain_english: Subjective interpretation expansively seeks an objective text, while the objective text compressively necessitates interpretation; therefore, normative Meaning is the compressive unity of both interpretation and text.

translation.plain_english: The subjective act of expression and the objective content expressed are mutually constitutive; neither is intelligible without the relation to the other.
translation.source_passage: what is expressed and the expression of it as individually intelligible independently of consideration of the relation between them... [is a temptation to be avoided].

translation.plain_english: The process of conceptual expression is the expansive codification of implicit practical ability (knowing-how) into explicit theoretical claim (knowing-that).
translation.source_passage: codifying some sort of knowing how in the form of a knowing that.

translation.plain_english: To possess a concept necessarily implies the capacity to utilize that concept within an inferential structure of reasoning.
translation.source_passage: To talk about concepts is to talk about roles in reasoning.

translation.plain_english: The objective category of Truth is necessarily determined by, and explanatorily subordinate to, the subjective social practice of Assertion.
translation.source_passage: Starting with an account of what one is doing in making a claim, it seeks to elaborate from it an account of what is said... something that can be thought of in terms of truth conditions

translation.plain_english: Conceptual content and the linguistic expression of that content are mutually constitutive; one cannot be intelligible without the other.
translation.source_passage: What is expressed must be understood in terms of the possibility of expressing it... linguistic performances and the intentional states they express [are] essential elements in a whole that is intelligible only in terms of their relation.

translation.plain_english: To possess a concept is necessarily to master its role in an inferential structure of reasons.
translation.source_passage: To talk about concepts is to talk about roles in reasoning... Grasping the concept... is mastering its inferential use.

translation.plain_english: The process of expression expansively transforms implicit practical know-how into explicit theoretical know-that.
translation.source_passage: The process of expression... [is] a matter... of making explicit what is implicit... codifying some sort of knowing how in the form of a knowing that.

translation.plain_english: The subjective experience of the Void (silence/lack of text) necessitates an expansive field of pure possibility, where anything could be meant but nothing yet is.
translation.source_passage: [Implicit silence of the input]

translation.plain_english: The act of interpretation collapses the expansive possibility of the Void into a specific, compressively necessary Meaning.
translation.source_passage: [The act of analysis itself]

translation.plain_english: The final Meaning does not destroy the Void but preserves it as a Horizon—the necessary context that borders and defines what is understood.
translation.source_passage: [The synthesis of text and silence]

translation.plain_english: True Understanding occurs when, and only when, the expansive possibilities of subjective Meaning are constrained and solidified by the compressive necessity of objective Validity.
translation.source_passage: HERMENEUTIC REFLECTION phase. The Parts rewrite the Whole.

translation.plain_english: A System is defined as the compressive necessity where the individual Part and the normative Whole mutually determine and imply one another.
translation.source_passage: The Parts rewrite the Whole.

translation.plain_english: True Understanding is defined as the necessary normative outcome where subjective anticipation and objective resistance are bound together; the subject's projection leads to resistance, which necessitates a modification of the view, creating a unified grasp of reality.
translation.source_passage: The Parts rewrite the Whole.

translation.plain_english: Meaning is the normative state where the expansive possibilities of the parts are restricted and defined by the compressive necessity of the whole structure.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Reflection phase.

translation.plain_english: If the Subjective Will necessitates expansive Action, and Objective Resistance necessitates compressive Limits, then the intersection of Action and Limit yields Normative Ethical Life.
translation.source_passage: The limit did not destroy the will but gave it definition... individual freedom is realized through communal norms.

translation.plain_english: The subjective assertion of pure identity necessarily compresses into the realization of difference.
translation.source_passage: Identity implies distinction.

translation.plain_english: The necessity of difference, when contextualized objectively as a relation, compresses into the normative structure of the concrete universal.
translation.source_passage: Truth is the whole.

translation.plain_english: The mutual alienation of Self and Other is structurally resolved into a necessary interdependence, where the subjective identity is bound to and realized through the objective other.
translation.source_passage: [Synthetic Reconstruction of prior analysis]

translation.plain_english: The Normative structure acts as the compressive force that necessitates a one-to-one correspondence between Subjective interpretation and Objective reality, thereby resolving their prior contradiction.
translation.source_passage: HERMENEUTIC REFLECTION phase. The Parts rewrite the Whole.

translation.plain_english: The objective content of concepts is necessarily determined by the normative rules of material inference (how terms relate in specific worldly contexts), rather than by abstract definitions.
translation.source_passage: The kind of inference whose correctnesses determine the conceptual contents of its premises and conclusions may be called... material inferences.

translation.plain_english: Formal logical validity is not a primitive structure but is necessarily derived from and defined by the stability of material correctness under the substitution of vocabulary.
translation.source_passage: The notion of formally valid inferences is definable in a natural way from that of materially correct ones, while there is no converse route.

translation.plain_english: Material inferences are primitive movements of reasoning, not 'broken' formal logic missing a hidden premise (enthymemes).
translation.source_passage: Mistakes ensue, however, if... the inference which finds its expression in ‘It is raining, therefore the streets will be wet’ is [treated as] an enthymeme.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of rationality expansively differentiates into two distinct statuses: the obligation of commitment and the authority of entitlement.
translation.source_passage: The question whether or not one is committed to a certain claim(able) must be distinct from the question whether or not one is entitled (by reasons) to that commitment.

translation.plain_english: Material incompatibility is compressively defined as the relationship where commitment to one claim necessitates the loss of entitlement to another.
translation.source_passage: We can say that two claims are materially incompatible in case commitment to one precludes entitlement to the other.

translation.plain_english: The logical operator of negation is necessarily derived from and constituted by the primitive normative relation of incompatibility.
translation.source_passage: For instance, one can define the negation of p as its minimum incompatible: it is the claim that is commitment entailed by every claim materially incompatible with p.

translation.plain_english: Even non-inferential observational reports necessarily depend on inferential articulation to possess normative conceptual content.
translation.source_passage: Even such noninferential reports must be inferentially articulated. Without that requirement, we cannot tell the difference between noninferential reporters and automatic...

translation.plain_english: The possession of any single normative concept expansively necessitates the possession of a systematic plurality of concepts.
translation.source_passage: For grasp of one concept consists in mastery of at least some of its inferential relations to other concepts. Cognitively, grasp of just one concept is the sound of one hand clapping.

translation.plain_english: The capacity for non-inferential reporting (observation) is necessarily dependent upon and derived from the capacity for inferential reasoning.
translation.source_passage: Another consequence is that to be able to apply one concept noninferentially, one must be able to use others inferentially... So the idea that there could be an autonomous language game... is a radical mistake.

translation.plain_english: The objective identity of conceptual content is compressively determined by, and equivalent to, the equivalence of inferential roles.
translation.source_passage: Two claims have the same conceptual content if and only if they have the same inferential role: a good inference is never turned into a bad one by substituting one for the other.

translation.plain_english: The objective content of a concept is necessarily constituted by the correctness of the material inferences it supports (e.g., from 'lightning' to 'thunder'), not by formal logical definitions.
translation.source_passage: It is the contents of the concepts west and east that make the first a good inference... Endorsing these inferences is part of grasping or mastering those concepts, quite apart from any specifically logical competence.

translation.plain_english: Formal validity is expansively generated by taking materially good inferences and holding a specific subset of vocabulary fixed while varying the rest.
translation.source_passage: an inference can be treated as good in virtue of its form... just in case It is a materially good inference, and It cannot be turned into a materially bad one by substituting...

translation.plain_english: The normative force of material inference expands beyond and is not reducible to logical form; rationality is not merely a logical capacity.
translation.source_passage: Often, however, inferential articulation is identified with logical articulation. Material inferences are accordingly treated as a derivative category... Mistakes ensue, however...

translation.plain_english: The status of formal validity is necessarily dependent upon and derived from the prior existence of material inferences; one cannot have valid forms without the content-based inferences they abstract from.
translation.source_passage: The kind of inference whose correctnesses determine the conceptual contents of its premises and conclusions may be called... material inferences.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of material inference expansively resists reduction to formal validity; it is not merely a 'gappy' logical argument waiting for a hidden premise.
translation.source_passage: Mistakes ensue, however, if... logical force of reasons [is restricted] to formally valid inferences... what Sellars calls 'the received dogma... that [it] is an enthymeme.'

translation.plain_english: Objective formal validity is compressively defined as material correctness that remains invariant under the subjective mechanism of vocabulary substitution.
translation.source_passage: Formal goodness of inferences derives from and is explained in terms of the material goodness of inferences... an inference can be treated as good in virtue of its form... just in case It is a materially good inference, and It cannot be turned into a materially bad one by substituting...

translation.plain_english: Logical validity is expansively derived from material inference through the subjective operation of substitution; a formally valid inference is just a material inference that remains good under all variable substitutions.
translation.source_passage: formal goodness of inferences derives from and is explained in terms of the material goodness of inferences... the notion of formally valid inferences is definable in a natural way from that of materially correct ones

translation.plain_english: Material inferences are compressively necessary in their own right and do not depend on the addition of hidden premises (enthymemes) to possess normative force.
translation.source_passage: The substantial commitment that is fundamental to this sort of approach is what Sellars calls 'the received dogma . . . that the inference... is an enthymeme.'

translation.plain_english: Normative material inference expands beyond and cannot be reduced to formally valid logic; attempting to do so (the Formalist Dogma) creates an explanatory gap.
translation.source_passage: Mistakes ensue, however, if the concept logical is employed... [to] restrict the notion of logical force of reasons to formally valid inferences.

translation.plain_english: The objective content of a concept is compressively determined by the material inferences it is caught up in.
translation.source_passage: His own position is that an expression has conceptual content conferred on it by being caught up in, playing a certain role in, material inferences.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of material inference functions expansively; it asserts a propriety of reasoning that cannot be reduced to or explained away as a formal logical schema with suppressed premises.
translation.source_passage: Mistakes ensue, however, if... logical force of reasons [is restricted] to formally valid inferences... [rejecting] 'the received dogma... that the inference... is an enthymeme.'

translation.plain_english: The objective content of a concept is necessarily constituted by the normative material inferences in which it plays a role.
translation.source_passage: It is the contents of the concepts west and east that make the first a good inference... Endorsing these inferences is part of grasping or mastering those concepts.

translation.plain_english: The status of formal logical inference is compressively necessary only as a derivative of, and dependent upon, the prior existence of material inferences.
translation.source_passage: Formal goodness of inferences derives from and is explained in terms of the material goodness of inferences, and so ought not to be appealed to in explaining it.

translation.plain_english: Formal validity is expansively defined as a state where the material correctness of an inference remains stable regardless of how non-logical vocabulary is substituted.
translation.source_passage: An inference can be treated as good in virtue of its form... just in case It is a materially good inference, and It cannot be turned into a materially bad one by substituting...

translation.plain_english: The normative goodness of an inference (meaning) is essentially constituted by material inference, without the compressive necessity of postulating hidden (enthymematic) premises.
translation.source_passage: The inference which finds its expression in ‘It is raining, therefore the streets will be wet’ is [not necessarily] an enthymeme.

translation.plain_english: The normative force of material inference expands beyond and cannot be reduced to mere logical form or hidden syllogisms (enthymemes).
translation.source_passage: Mistakes ensue, however, if the concept logical is employed... to restrict the notion of logical force of reasons to formally valid inferences.

translation.plain_english: Normative Freedom is defined as the state where the compressive necessity of the Subject's Will and the expansive necessity of Objective Law are mutually active and unified.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Synthesis

translation.plain_english: Within the state of Freedom, subjective Duty becomes identical to objective Necessity; what one ought to do is what must be done.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Synthesis

translation.plain_english: The Socratic method is the expansive necessity whereby implicit subjective practices are transformed into explicit objective rules that can be debated.
translation.source_passage: Socratic method serves the purpose of making explicit the rules we have adopted for thought and action... making explicit, in the form of assertible rules, commitments that had hitherto remained implicit in inferential practices.

translation.plain_english: Modal statements (claims of necessity or possibility) function as compressive inference licenses; they do not describe the world directly but authorize transitions in reasoning.
translation.source_passage: Sellars understands such modal statements as inference licenses, which formulate as the content of a claim the appropriateness of inferential transitions.

translation.plain_english: Logical notation (like Frege's concept-script) functions expansively not to prove formal truths, but to express and codify the material conceptual content of scientific claims.
translation.source_passage: The task of the work is officially an expressive one: not to prove something but to say something. Frege’s logical notation is designed for expressing conceptual contents...

translation.plain_english: The logical conditional ('if P then Q') is the compressive codification of the subjective act of inferring, allowing us to say explicitly what we previously only did implicitly.
translation.source_passage: Frege’s aim is to introduce vocabulary that will let one say (explicitly) what otherwise one can only do (implicitly). Consider the conditional...

translation.plain_english: The subjective emptiness of the input necessitates an expansive interpretation of infinite possibility.
translation.source_passage: [Empty Input]

translation.plain_english: The normative context of the system rules necessitates a compressive determination of what creates meaning.
translation.source_passage: System Instructions / Schema

translation.plain_english: Meaning is necessarily produced by the sublation (simultaneous cancellation and preservation) of infinite potential by structural determination.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Reflection Phase

translation.plain_english: The Subject, posits its own existence as a necessary and complete Identity.
translation.source_passage: The self begins as a closed circle, assuming it is the whole of reality.

translation.plain_english: The presence of the Object (the Other) creates an expansive necessity that negates the Subject's initial Identity.
translation.source_passage: But the appearance of another consciousness rips the fabric of this solitary universe.

translation.plain_english: Recognition is defined normatively as the compressive necessity binding the Self and the Other together; neither can exist as a self-conscious agent without the other.
translation.source_passage: Reflecting on the resolution of the master-slave dialectic.

translation.plain_english: The nature of rationality is expansively defined by the movement from implicit subjective practice (doing) to explicit objective claim (saying).
translation.source_passage: Socratic method serves the purpose of making explicit the rules we have adopted for thought and action... making explicit in a form that can be thought or said what is implicit in what is done.

translation.plain_english: Once a commitment is made explicit as a claim, it is necessarily compressed under the authority of normative rational control, meaning it can be challenged and requires justification.
translation.source_passage: Socratic method is a way of bringing our practices under rational control by expressing them explicitly in a form in which they can be confronted with objections and alternatives.

translation.plain_english: Logical form functions compressively as the 'cement' that necessarily binds together the material contents of a language into a coherent system.
translation.source_passage: What we still lack is the logical cement that will bind these building stones firmly together.

translation.plain_english: The logical conditional expansively codifies the subjective act of inferring into an objective statement, allowing one to say explicitly what one previously only did implicitly.
translation.source_passage: After conditional locutions have been introduced, one can say, explicitly, what otherwise one can only do implicitly.

translation.plain_english: Normative Truth is defined as the simultaneous holding of internal self-consistency (subjective compression) and external validity (objective expansion).
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Reflection Phase (Synthesis)

translation.plain_english: Given the normative status of the conclusion (the End) and the subjective act of understanding it, the Beginning is necessarily redefined as equivalent to the End.
translation.source_passage: HERMENEUTIC REFLECTION phase.

translation.plain_english: The subjective reading of a specific passage necessarily points toward a global context, while the objective global context strictly determines the meaning of the specific passage; true Meaning exists only in the intersection of these two movements.
translation.source_passage: General Hermeneutic Principle (Implicit)

translation.plain_english: When a concept is negated and that negation is itself negated, the original concept is not merely restored but established as necessary and preserved within a higher framework.
translation.source_passage: Structural Summary

translation.plain_english: If the Subject asserts P, and the Object asserts not-P, and this conflict is structurally necessary, then in the Normative context, the Subject and Object are necessarily defined by their relation to one another.
translation.source_passage: General philosophical inference of the final dialectical stage.

translation.plain_english: If a Norm exists, and it is necessarily self-reinforcing, then the Subject subjective appropriates this Norm as its own will.
translation.source_passage: Inference regarding the internalization of the law.

translation.plain_english: The subjective experience of the Self, when viewed as infinite possibility, inevitably generates the concept of 'that which is not Self' (the Object) as a logical consequence of its own expansion.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Review of Phase 1

translation.plain_english: The simultaneous existence of the Subject and the Object creates a compressive necessity: a Limit that defines where one ends and the other begins.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Review of Phase 2

translation.plain_english: The subjective Self necessarily expands to encounter the objective Other, and the objective Other compressively determines the Self; therefore, Normative Recognition is equivalent to the mutual implication of Self and Other.
translation.source_passage: Synthesized from the cumulative trajectory of the analysis.

translation.plain_english: Normative meaning is established if and only if subjective intent is externalized through expansive expression and simultaneously disciplined by the compressive limits of objective structure.
translation.source_passage: [Hermeneutic Reflection Phase - Synthetic Summary]

translation.plain_english: Once Truth is established normatively, it must be re-internalized by the subject, starting the cycle anew at a higher order.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic Reflection Phase (Return)

translation.plain_english: A genuine belief is lawfully defined as the compressive unity of an objective differential response (reliability) and a normative capacity for inferential articulation (reasoning).
translation.source_passage: Beliefs... are essentially things that can serve as premises and conclusions of inferences... The subject of genuine perceptual beliefs is, as the parrot is not... applying a concept.

translation.plain_english: Objective reliability, no matter how perfect, expansively fails to generate or explain normative conceptual content; reliability tracks truth, but does not constitute meaning.
translation.source_passage: I call the failure to realize this limitation on the explanatory powers of the concept of reliability the ‘Conceptual Blindspot’ of reliabilism.

translation.plain_english: The practice of giving and asking for reasons is structurally autonomous (can exist on its own), whereas the intelligibility of reliability is parasitic on the existence of reason-giving practices.
translation.source_passage: Practices in which some beliefs are accorded the status of true and justified are autonomous... Practices in which the only status beliefs can have... is having been reliably produced are not autonomous.

translation.plain_english: To possess a concept is necessarily to treat a response as a node within a normative network of commitments, premises, and conclusions.
translation.source_passage: No response that is not a node in a network of such broadly inferential involvements, I claim, is recognizable as the application of concepts.

translation.plain_english: The Reliabilist hypothesis expansively claims that if belief, truth, and probability are natural facts, then Knowledge itself implies a reduction to purely objective natural facts.
translation.source_passage: if the concept of reliability can do the work previously done by notions of evidence... then a naturalistic account of knowledge is possible.

translation.plain_english: The determination of an objective probability is necessarily dependent upon the subjective selection of a reference class.
translation.source_passage: An objective probability can be specified only relative to a reference class... the proper choice of reference class is not itself objectively determined by facts specifiable in a naturalistic vocabulary.

translation.plain_english: Objective Nature expansively fails to determine the correct Reference Class; the world does not tell us which grouping is the relevant one for assessing reliability.
translation.source_passage: the world as it objectively is... does not in general privilege one of the competing universe of possible reference classes as the correct or appropriate one.

translation.plain_english: The combination of a proper Causal Link, subjective Justification, and objective Truth is necessarily insufficient to constitute Knowledge (due to environmental luck).
translation.source_passage: The perceiver has a true belief, has good reasons... and stands in the right causal relations... [but] does he know there is a red barn in front of him? A good case can be made that he does not.

translation.plain_english: If an agent possesses a reliable mechanism and subjectively knows they possess it, this reliability is compressed into a normative justification (a reason).
translation.source_passage: In the standard case, we would expect that a reliable chicken-sexer would come to believe that he is reliable... provides an appropriate inferential justification.

translation.plain_english: It is expansively possible for a subject to hold a genuine belief without possessing a normative reason or entitlement for it (e.g., blind conviction).
translation.source_passage: Cognitively irresponsible beliefs can genuinely be beliefs. And in these very special cases, such irresponsible beliefs can qualify as knowledge.

translation.plain_english: Subjective knowledge is possible in local instances where objective reliability and truth are present, even without the subject's access to reasons.
translation.source_passage: Knowledge based on reliability without the subject’s having reasons for it is possible as a local phenomenon...

translation.plain_english: However, for a system of practice to exist at all, it compressively necessitates the game of giving and asking for reasons; reliability alone cannot sustain a practice.
translation.source_passage: But not as a global one... the reason-giving practices that the classical justificatory internalist takes as paradigmatic ingredients of knowledge are autonomous in this sense.

translation.plain_english: Isolated instances of 'blind' knowledge are necessarily dependent on a background global system of reason-giving practices to be intelligible.
translation.source_passage: Put differently, do belief-forming practices of the sort that motivate the Founding Insight form an autonomous set...?

translation.plain_english: The normative status of holding a belief is expansively distinct from and irreducible to the objective status of being a reliable indicator (like a thermometer or parrot).
translation.source_passage: But the reasons forwarded thus far are at best probative, not dispositive... The world is full of reliable indicators. Chunks of iron rust... But they cannot treat themselves or one another as doing that.

translation.plain_english: A state qualifies as a belief if and only if it functions necessarily as a node within a normative network of inference (serving as premise or conclusion).
translation.source_passage: Beliefs... are essentially things that can serve as premises and conclusions of inferences... No response that is not a node in a network of such broadly inferential involvements, I claim, is recognizable as the application of concepts.

translation.plain_english: The intelligibility of the concept of 'reliability' is necessarily dependent upon the prior existence of the normative practice of giving reasons.
translation.source_passage: Their intelligibility is parasitic on that of the reason-giving practices that underwrite ordinary ascriptions of knowledge.

translation.plain_english: A practice consisting solely of reliable indicators without reason-giving is expansively insufficient to be an autonomous language game.
translation.source_passage: Practices in which the only status beliefs can have besides being true is having been reliably produced are not autonomous in that sense.

translation.plain_english: Reliabilist epistemology expansively fails to account for the semantics of belief; it cannot explain what makes a state a belief in the first place.
translation.source_passage: I call the failure to realize this limitation on the explanatory powers of the concept of reliability the 'Conceptual Blindspot' of reliabilism.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of Knowledge functions expansively to resist reduction to mere objective Probability; knowing is not simply a high statistical likelihood of being right.
translation.source_passage: appeals to objective probability fall short of enabling fully naturalistic accounts of knowledge

translation.plain_english: Knowledge expansively transcends and is not reducible to a mere causal link between the believer and the object, as a perfect causal link can exist in a context where knowledge is absent.
translation.source_passage: It also shows that appeal to the causal chain linking the believer to what his belief is about is not adequate to distinguish knowledge from merely accidentally true belief.

translation.plain_english: Objective probability is not a self-standing natural fact; it is necessarily constituted by and dependent upon the normative selection of a reference class.
translation.source_passage: An objective probability can be specified only relative to a reference class... the proper choice of reference class is not itself objectively determined by facts specifiable in a naturalistic vocabulary.

translation.plain_english: The totality of objective natural facts expansively fails to determine the correct reference class; nature alone does not tell us which context is the relevant one for assessing reliability.
translation.source_passage: The world as it objectively is... does not in general privilege one of the competing universe of possible reference classes as the correct or appropriate one.

translation.plain_english: The objective context (e.g., the presence of facades) necessitates that subjective justification, even if true, fails to achieve the status of Knowledge; context defeats internal sufficiency.
translation.source_passage: For though he has a true belief, it is only accidentally true. It is true only because he happened to stumble on the one real barn out of a thousand apparent ones.

translation.plain_english: The objective facts of the world, considered in isolation from human interests, do not expansively determine which reference class is the 'correct' one.
translation.source_passage: the world as it objectively is... does not in general privilege one of the competing universe of possible reference classes as the correct or appropriate one.

translation.plain_english: Knowledge necessitates not only a valid local causal link but also compatibility with the broader objective context (environment), such that the truth is not accidental.
translation.source_passage: But things are less clear as we describe the case further, moving to facts external to the perceiver’s beliefs... It is just an accident that he happened on the one real barn.

translation.plain_english: The normative concept of Reliability functions expansively and cannot be reduced to or fully explained by the objective concept of statistical Probability.
translation.source_passage: When we understand properly the sense in which facts about the reliability of a mechanism can be objective, we see that appeals to objective probability fall short of enabling fully naturalistic accounts of knowledge

translation.plain_english: Knowledge is compressively defined by its sensitivity to the modal context (counterfactual possibilities in the environment), not just the actual causal chain.
translation.source_passage: For though he has a true belief, it is only accidentally true. It is true only because he happened to stumble on the one real barn out of a thousand apparent ones.

translation.plain_english: The objective natural world expansively contains infinite possible groupings and does not, by itself, determine which reference class is appropriate for a given inquiry.
translation.source_passage: But the proper choice of reference class is not itself objectively determined by facts specifiable in a naturalistic vocabulary.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of Knowledge necessitates the exclusion of accidental truth; a belief that is true merely by luck does not qualify as knowledge.
translation.source_passage: For though he has a true belief, it is only accidentally true... This seems to be a case of exactly the sort that... was introduced to exclude.

translation.plain_english: The determination of an objective probability necessarily depends upon and is compressed by the subjective selection of a reference class; the world does not self-sort into probabilities.
translation.source_passage: An objective probability can be specified only relative to a reference class... the proper choice of reference class is not itself objectively determined by facts specifiable in a naturalistic vocabulary.

translation.plain_english: Natural facts about the world expansively fail to uniquely determine which reference class is the correct one for assessing reliability.
translation.source_passage: the world as it objectively is... does not in general privilege one of the competing universe of possible reference classes as the correct or appropriate one.

translation.plain_english: Knowledge compressively necessitates that the belief remain true across the relevant environmental context (robustness), rather than being true merely by accident.
translation.source_passage: It is true only because he happened to stumble on the one real barn out of a thousand apparent ones. This seems to be a case of exactly the sort that... was introduced to exclude.

translation.plain_english: Knowledge is compressively defined as a state where the conjunction of subjective belief and objective truth is not accidental.
translation.source_passage: For though he has a true belief, it is only accidentally true... This seems to be a case of exactly the sort that the third condition on knowledge... was introduced to exclude.

translation.plain_english: A proper account of Knowledge compressively requires both objective reliability and a subjective interest that defines the relevant reference class; it cannot be purely naturalistic.
translation.source_passage: appeals to objective probability fall short of enabling fully naturalistic accounts of knowledge

translation.plain_english: True Autonomy (in the normative sense) is equivalent to the compressive necessity of uniting the Subjective Will with Objective Reality; freedom is the recognition of necessity.
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic synthesis of the implied dialectic.

translation.plain_english: The ambition of naturalistic reliabilism is to compress the normative status of Knowledge into the objective scientific fact of Likelihood (probability).
translation.source_passage: Reliabilism promises a recipe for extending the one sort of account to the other... a naturalistic story about objective likelihood.

logic.conclusion_symbolic: exp_nec((s(Justification) land o(Truth) land o(Deceptive_Context)) implies not n(Knowledge))

translation.plain_english: Even if a subject has justification and truth, the presence of a deceptive objective environment (like barn facades) expansively negates the possibility of knowledge by rendering the truth accidental.
translation.source_passage: For though he has a true belief, it is only accidentally true... This seems to be a case of exactly the sort that... was introduced to exclude.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of Reliability is strictly equivalent to, and constituted by, the Subjective Explanatory Interests that define the relevant situation.
translation.source_passage: But the proper choice of reference class is not itself objectively determined by facts specifiable in a naturalistic vocabulary. So there is something left over.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of Knowledge expansively requires not just actual truth, but stability across relevant counterfactual contexts (it cannot be merely accidentally true).
translation.source_passage: For though he has a true belief, it is only accidentally true... It is just an accident that he happened on the one real barn out of a thousand apparent ones.

translation.plain_english: Normative reliability is the compressive unity of an objective mechanism working within a subjectively determined field of interest (reference class).
translation.source_passage: The world as it objectively is, apart from our subjective interests and concerns... does not in general privilege one of the competing universe of possible reference classes.

translation.plain_english: Normative Recognition consists of the condition where the Subjective Self implies the reality of the Objective Other, and simultaneously, the Other (as Subject) implies the reality of the Self.
translation.source_passage: [Synthesized Context] The truth of self-consciousness is not the 'I' alone, but the 'We'.

translation.plain_english: Freedom is not the absence of constraint, but the compressive necessity of existing within a structure of Mutual Recognition.
translation.source_passage: [Synthesized Context] Only in the other do I possess myself freely.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of Knowledge expands beyond and cannot be reduced to natural facts because it requires the non-natural specification of a reference class.
translation.source_passage: appeals to objective probability fall short of enabling fully naturalistic accounts of knowledge... So there is something left over.

translation.plain_english: The totality of objective natural facts (such as frequencies in the world) expansively fails to uniquely determine a verdict of reliability, because nature alone does not select which reference class is relevant.
translation.source_passage: I submit that the facts as described do not determine an answer... nothing in the way the world is privileges one of those reference classes... An argument place remains to be filled in

translation.plain_english: The normative status of reliability is necessarily dependent upon and constituted by the subjective description or specification of the mechanism and believer.
translation.source_passage: the reliability of the belief-forming mechanism... varies depending on how we describe the mechanism and the believer.

translation.plain_english: The epistemological significance of reliability is necessarily to be understood as a concern with the goodness of a distinctive kind of inference, rather than as a brute causal property.
translation.source_passage: concern with reliability should itself be understood as concern with the goodness of a distinctive kind of inference.

translation.plain_english: To attribute knowledge is necessarily to attribute two distinct normative statuses: a commitment (belief as a stance in a network) and an entitlement (justification or right) to that commitment.
translation.source_passage: So to take someone to know something, one must do two things: attribute a certain kind of inferentially articulated commitment, and attribute a certain kind of entitlement to that commitment.

translation.plain_english: The normative status of knowledge expansively implies and requires the reliability of the process that produced it; one cannot know if one's method is merely lucky.
translation.source_passage: Reliabilism promises a recipe for extending the one sort of account to the other... if the concept of reliability can do the work previously done by notions of evidence.

translation.plain_english: In the objective context, the Object must necessarily expand into something distinct from the observer.
translation.source_passage: The interpretive journey begins with the positing of an external Object...

translation.plain_english: The expansive distinctness of the object, when filtered through subjective categories, is compressed into a necessary mediation.
translation.source_passage: ...properties of the Object are inevitably framed by the Subject's own categories.

translation.plain_english: This mediation necessitates a normative context of Self-Consciousness, where the distinction is overcome.
translation.source_passage: ...sublation of both abstract Subject and abstract Object into the Absolute...

translation.plain_english: If subjective intent necessarily requires objective structure to exist, and objective structure necessarily opens up possibilities for subjective intent, then we must conclude that Normative Understanding is the necessary binding together of Intent and Structure.
translation.source_passage: HERMENEUTIC REFLECTION phase.

translation.plain_english: Given the established state of Recognition, the existence of both the distinct Self and the distinct Other is now understood as a compressive necessity (they cannot be otherwise).
translation.source_passage: Hermeneutic deduction.

translation.plain_english: Communication is expansively defined as the interpersonal process where entitlement to a commitment is passed from a speaker to a hearer, allowing the hearer to use it as a premise.
translation.source_passage: Thus one essential aspect of this model of discursive practice is communication: the interpersonal, intra-content inheritance of entitlement to commitments.

translation.plain_english: Justification is the compressive necessity of redeeming one's entitlement to a commitment when challenged, thereby maintaining it within one's own score.
translation.source_passage: Thus another essential aspect of this model of discursive practice is justification: the intrapersonal, intercontent inheritance of entitlement to commitments.

translation.plain_english: To understand propositional content is necessarily to master the practical game of scorekeeping—tracking what commitments and entitlements interlocutors have.
translation.source_passage: Understanding or grasping such a propositional content is a kind of know-how... To play such a game is to keep score on what various interlocutors are committed and entitled to.

translation.plain_english: The objective status of Truth is compressed into the subjective stance of the scorekeeper; to take a claim as true is simply to undertake that commitment oneself.
translation.source_passage: For the scorekeeper to take the attributed claim to be true is just for the scorekeeper to endorse that claim. That is... the scorekeeper himself undertake the same commitment attributed to the candidate knower.

translation.plain_english: The objective representational dimension of language (what it is 'about') arises expansively from the social difference between attributing a commitment to another and undertaking it oneself.
translation.source_passage: The story I want to tell, then, is how the implicit representational dimension of the inferential contents of claims arises out of the difference in social perspective between producers and consumers of reasons.

translation.plain_english: The structural form of language (singular terms and predicates) is necessarily derived from the combination of two demands: the need for new sentences to be understandable (projectibility) and the need for implicit practices to be made explicit (logical explicitation).
translation.source_passage: It is these two expressive demands... that jointly give rise to the structure of symmetrically significant substituted-fors and asymmetrically significant substitution-structural sentence frames.

translation.plain_english: The logical conditional ('if... then...') functions compressively by inverting the inferential direction of its antecedent, creating a hostile environment for asymmetric roles.
translation.source_passage: For to play its inference-explicitating role, the conditional, for instance, must form compound sentences whose antecedent substitution position is inferentially inverting.

translation.plain_english: Because the conditional inverts inferences, the basic units of language (singular terms) must possess symmetric significance (identity) to remain stable under substitution in all contexts.
translation.source_passage: Only symmetrically significant expressions can be substituted for, and so form sentence frames, in such a context.

translation.plain_english: The existence of objects in the world is necessarily determined by the existence of singular terms in language; ontology is a shadow of grammar.
translation.source_passage: To ask the question 'Why are there singular terms?' is one way of asking the question 'Why are there objects?'

translation.plain_english: Logical vocabulary expansively lifts implicit subjective habits into the explicit normative light of the 'discursive marketplace,' where they can be criticized as public reasons.
translation.source_passage: Logic makes it possible for the development of the concepts... to rise in part above the indistinct realm of mere tradition... and enter the comparatively well lit discursive marketplace.

translation.plain_english: Truth is not a primitive object found in the world, but is compressively defined as that which is preserved by good inferences; logic determines ontology.
translation.source_passage: define truth as what is preserved by good inferences.

translation.plain_english: A Knower is distinct from a mere responder (like a parrot) because the Knower expansively integrates their reliable responses into an inferential network.
translation.source_passage: The knower is able to use the differentially elicited response in inference... The parrot and the thermostat lack the concepts... precisely because they lack the practical mastery of the inferential articulation

translation.plain_english: The objective representational dimension of thought (what it is about) is expansively generated by the combination of inferential articulation and social practice.
translation.source_passage: the representational dimension of discourse reflects the fact that conceptual content is not only inferentially articulated but also socially articulated.

translation.plain_english: The essence of intentionality is not subjective Certainty (Descartes) but normative Necessity or bindingness (Kant).
translation.source_passage: Kant launched a new philosophical epoch by shifting the center of concern from certainty to necessity.

translation.plain_english: Understanding linguistic meaning is compressively defined as the practical mastery of keeping score on the commitments and entitlements of oneself and others.
translation.source_passage: Mastering such linguistic practices is a matter of learning how to keep score on the inferentially articulated commitments and entitlements

translation.plain_english: The objective representational content of a claim (what it is about) is necessarily derived from and constituted by the social practice of inferential articulation.
translation.source_passage: The large task is to show what it is about that inferential articulation in virtue of which claimable contents are therefore also representational contents.

translation.plain_english: Normative commitment expansively includes both what one subjectively acknowledges (avows) and the consequential commitments that logically follow, even if unintended.
translation.source_passage: These correspond to two senses of 'believe'... the sense in which one believes only what one takes oneself to believe, and the sense in which one believes willy-nilly whatever one’s beliefs commit one to.

translation.plain_english: The function of ascriptional vocabulary (like 'believes that') is to expansively transform the implicit practical attitude of attributing commitments into an explicit objective claim that can be debated.
translation.source_passage: Ascribing beliefs or commitments is making that implicit practical attitude explicit in the form of a claim.

translation.plain_english: A 'De Re' ascription (claiming *of* someone) compressively binds two distinct responsibilities: the ascriber undertakes the reference (the object), while attributing the predication to the target.
translation.source_passage: My suggestion is that the expressive function of de re ascriptions... is to make explicit which aspects of what is said express commitments that are being attributed and which express commitments that are undertaken.

translation.plain_english: The capacity to make de re ascriptions necessitates the distinction between the objective referent (what we are talking about) and the subjective sense (how the target thinks about it).
translation.source_passage: The disagreement is about whether this guy is a liar, not about whether liars make trustworthy witnesses... The defense attorney claims of a pathological liar that he is a trustworthy witness.

translation.plain_english: A 'de dicto' ascription compressively binds the content of a belief strictly to the specific phrasing or dictum acknowledged by the subject (e.g., believing 'that' p).

prose.summary: In this final hermeneutic reflection, the distinction between the analyzing subject and the analyzed object is overcome. The fragments of logic identified in earlier phases are revealed not as static axioms, but as dynamic moments of a single self-referential totality.
prose.conceptual_narrative: We began with the isolation of specific terms (the Parts), treating them as discrete atomic units of meaning. However, the expansive necessity of these terms forced them beyond their boundaries—a Part cannot exist without the context it implies. As we aggregated these implications, a new compressive necessity emerged: the Whole. The Whole is not merely the sum of the Parts, but the active force that retroactively determines what the Parts mean. In this final synthesis, the linear timeline of reading is sublated. The End (the Whole) is recognized as having been the driving cause of the Beginning (the Parts). The contradiction between the plurality of axioms and the unity of the argument is resolved in the Concrete Universal, where diversity is the very form of unity.
prose.interpretive_notes: The logic implies a circular causality typical of high dialectics: s(Part) generates exp_nec(Context), which crystallizes into o(Whole), which in turn exerts comp_nec(Definition) back upon the Part.

prose.summary: This introductory section establishes the strategic landscape for 'Articulating Reasons'. Brandom defines his project as an investigation into the nature of the 'conceptual', distinguished sharply from mere 'sentience' or non-discursive complexity. The core thesis—Inferentialism—is immediately posited: conceptual content is constituted by its role in reasoning, reversing the traditional order which prioritizes reference (representation) over inference. The text outlines a methodological commitment to 'Differentiation' (focusing on the discontinuity between sapient and non-sapient creatures) and 'Pragmatism' (explaining conceptual content in terms of the practice of using concepts), explicitly rejecting 'Assimilation' and 'Platonism'.
prose.conceptual_narrative: The dialectic begins by isolating 'The Conceptual' as a unique domain of 'Sapience'. Rather than viewing the mind as a passive mirror (Platonism/Representationalism) or merely a complex biological feedback loop (Assimilation), the text positions the conceptual as a distinctively 'Normative' space of reasons. The movement is from the 'Implicit' doing of non-discursive creatures to the 'Explicit' reasoning of sapient beings. Brandom argues that we must first understand the *activity* (Pragmatism) of inference to derive the *objectivity* of content, effectively sublating the static notion of 'meaning' into the dynamic notion of 'use'.
prose.interpretive_notes: The text abruptly cuts off during the definition of Platonism, but the trajectory is clear: Platonism (content explains use) is the thesis to be inverted by Pragmatism (use explains content). This inversion is the foundational move of the book's logic.

prose.summary: In this introductory chunk, Robert Brandom establishes the strategic context for 'Articulating Reasons'. He defines the 'conceptual' not as a static possession of abstract meanings, but as a dynamic capacity for 'sapience'—specifically, the ability to play a role in reasoning. He outlines two fundamental methodological choices governing his project: 1) 'Differentiation' over 'Assimilation', asserting a sharp discontinuity between the normative activity of concept-users (sapience) and the causal behavior of non-discursive creatures (sentience); and 2) 'Pragmatism' over 'Platonism', prioritizing the study of concept-use (practice) to explain conceptual content, rather than assuming content exists prior to its use.
prose.conceptual_narrative: The investigation begins by inverting the traditional order of semantic explanation. Where classical views might posit 'representation' or 'meaning' as the foundation of mind, this framework posits 'inference' as the primitive. This is the move to Inferentialism. To achieve this, the text performs a 'Pragmatic Turn': we do not start with Platonist entities (meanings) and ask how we grasp them; we start with the messy, subjective practice of doing things (reasoning) and show how objective conceptual content emerges from it. Furthermore, the text rejects the naturalistic urge to smooth over the difference between humans and animals. Instead, it highlights 'Sapience' as a unique normative status—a discontinuity where the rules of logic and reason emerge not from biology, but from the social game of giving and asking for reasons.
prose.interpretive_notes: Brandom's distinction between 'sapience' and 'sentience' is crucial here. Sentience is treated as a biological/causal state (s), while Sapience is treated as a normative status (n). The logic reflects this by showing that Sapience cannot be simply expanded from Sentience; it requires a different modal operation (compressive determination by norms).
